awd_titl_txt: Scale-Dependent Observability of Emergent Dynamics: Application to Traffic Flow with Connected Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
Global emergent patterns are observed in several large-scale complex systems, such as transportation networks, power grids, and financial markets. Gaining understanding of these dynamically evolving behavioral patterns is very important to solve problems associated with such systems. For example, in transportation networks, these emergent patterns usually dictate congestion dynamics and are poised to undergo a transformative change with the introduction of connected vehicles that can communicate with each other. Consequently, our ability to observe such patterns plays a critical role in effectively managing the transition to a smarter transportation network as well as in improving system performance and reducing congestion costs. This research seeks to answer questions about the appropriate scale at which these patterns may be best observed. Additionally, this work also seeks to assess the effect of varying penetration rates of connected vehicles on the ability to observe emergent patterns in traffic. This work has a great potential to significantly improve our ability to monitor, predict and control the occurrence of emergent congestion events. In the case of traffic flow applications, this study could help reduce worldwide congestion costs that are estimated to be in several hundreds of billions of US dollars annually. The techniques developed during this study will enhance our fundamental knowledge about how to observe the emergent behavior and use this knowledge to analyze and solve the problems associated with several other complex systems. The project also has highly innovative educational plan of creating visually appealing and lucid graphics material to engage undergraduate and graduate students, as well as the general public.

The primary objective of this research project is to create a rigorous methodology to determine the spatial scale and model order required to observe and predict emergent phenomena in complex systems. In a narrower context of traffic flow, the project seeks to establish the modeling requirements for observing emergent congestion events on a multi-lane highway, and predicting such behavior with better accuracy than current prediction models. The approach will modify existing Krylov subspace-based model order reduction techniques by explicitly incorporating spatial scales into the process. More importantly, the novel contribution of this work will be the control-theoretic formulation of the renormalization group theory borrowed from the field of statistical mechanics to gain an understanding of how the observability of emergent dynamics depends on spatial scale. The research will include the study of spatial dependence of observability in complex systems in a control-theoretic setting. This work will also contribute to the study of how penetration rate (i.e., the distribution of a sensor network in a complex system) impacts the observability of emergent behavior in complex traffic flow dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
The study of traffic flow is especially important as highway traffic congestion on our roadways is increasing rapidly, and its economic, environment, and societal costs continue to rise as well. The management of traffic systems requires a deeper understanding of how vehicular flow changes over time. This study can be performed using data or via modeling techniques. There have been significant recent advances (such as with Google Maps) that make it possible to predict future traffic situations, but a large majority of these rely of historical data alone, whereas incorporation of computer-amenable models could have improve prediction capabilities. Existing models typically examine traffic flow at too large of a scale (e.g., modeling it as flow of fluids) or are too small (e.g., modeling individual vehicles as particles). Modeling at both these scales makes it difficult to build appropriate traffic control policies, which may perform best if they used intermediate scale models.

In addition, being able to observe the state of the traffic is also an important challenge and can help predict what the future state might be. This is an important consideration for designing traffic control policies, since it is difficult to design control policies without knowing the current state of traffic flow.

In this work, we build intermediate (or mesoscopic) scale models that are also amenable to computer simulation and modeling. Specifically, these models draw inspiration from relatively simple physics models, such as the Ising model and cellular automata models. We also create measures of observability for these models. Previous research work has examined both these aspects, but to our knowledge, this has never been done together (i.e., observability of mesoscopic scale traffic flow models has not been studied). We use physics-inspired modeling and scaling tools, such as renormalization group theory, to study traffic flow using the same model but at different scales. This work is performed by ‘coarsening’ the model by changing only the function parameters, and without changing the functional form of the model itself.

We found that using these physics-inspired renormalization group tools can indeed help us model traffic flows at multiple scales, while retaining the ability to describe its evolution. We also used information theory-based tools, such as mutual information metrics, to study the observability of the traffic flow model. Our work shows that

(a) simple models can replicate traffic behavior,

(b) these simple models can be transformed into a manageable scale while retaining the ability to model traffic, and

(c) we can determine if the observations can help identify if the traffic is jammed or congested.

A first important scientific outcome is that the ability of a single vehicle to observe the traffic state increases when it encounters traffic jams. This is interesting, because the being able to observe the traffic is shown to actually correspond to the situation where the vehicle will be least able to control the system (since it is inside a traffic jam). This indicates that there is a trade-off between being able to observe the traffic flow, and the ability to control it. We continue to study this this trade-off in a subsequent project.

Another important scientific outcome is that we can use simple-to-simulate physics-based Ising and/or cellular automata models that can run faster than real-time. This will make traffic flow projections easier. Being able to choose the scale at which to simulate the traffic flow system provides additional fine-tuning capability to select a model best suited for a given traffic flow scenario. Indeed, these approaches can be used to model a wide variety of scale-dependent systems, such as weather, if they can be adapted to a cellular automata framework.

This project enabled the training of one Ph.D. student who, in addition to performing the scientific work, also learned to present at conferences, was trained in traffic flow simulation software by attending AIMSUN workshops, and learned to better communicate scientific results by publishing three conference papers and who has finished writing two manuscripts for journal publication. In addition to this, the work also partially funded one undergraduate student in the Arts department, who created comic-based outreach to better explain the concepts of self-organization in traffic flows to the public.
